protocol_name: Most Probable Number (MPN) Counts of Cyanophages
protocol_name_html: Most Probable Number (MPN) Counts of Cyanophages
description: Purpose: to measure the infective titer (number of infective elements per mL) of from 1-5 viral samples in a quick and efficient manner.
protocol_affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, Ohio State University

authors_list.name: Bonnie Poulos
authors_list.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, Ohio State University

guidelines:
(Modified from R. Fu, K. Frois-Moniz & M. Sullivan protocol)

Materials: (assuming 2 replicates per viral sample)

• Two sterile, flat-bottom, 96-well plates for up to 5 viral samples with a capacity for >300 µL
• 30 mL Pro99 or SN medium for each dilution plate plus 30 mL for each sample test plate
• 7 mL late-exponential phase host cells (~3x107/mL)
• 60 µL each virus sample
• Multi-channel pipettor with 12x300 µL and 8x1500 µL heads and a 20-100 µL pipette
• Sterile tips for pipettors
• Sterile plastic troughs for cells and growth medium for use with multi-channel pipettors
• Parafilm for sealing lids to prevent evaporation

Labeling example for step 1

 

 

Virus Sample A

Virus Sample B

Virus Sample C

Virus Sample D

Virus Sample E

-1  H

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Calculations: for calculation purposes, each well contains 30 µL of cells mixed with 20 µL phage, diluted with 200 µL medium for a total of 250 µL.

Note: once you have prepared the phage dilutions, the rest of the procedure should be carried out as quickly as possible to minimize (a) possible viral adhesion to the plates and (b) the amount of time that the host cells spend out of the incubator.

source_data.annotation: You should replace the tips with fresh ones for each column. If you are testing several different hosts, you can set the pipettor to step up to 10 times at 20 µL and inoculate up to 10 different hosts, each in a separate test plate.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 15 of Most Probable Number (MPN) Counts of Cyanophages

source_data.protocol_name_html: Most Probable Number (MPN) Counts of Cyanophages
source_data.annotation: Plates may be read in 1-2 weeks, however, it might be preferable to get an initial reading on the plates and monitor progress every 2-3 days. We use the Appliskan plate reader, set to read fluorescent emission using a 485 µm excitation filter and a 675 µm (for green fluorescence) or 590 µm (for red fluorescence) emission filter.
source_data.thread_text: Plates may be read in 1-2 weeks, however, it might be preferable to get an initial reading on the plates and monitor progress every 2-3 days. We use the Appliskan plate reader, set to read fluorescent emission using a 485 µm excitation filter and a 675 µm (for green fluorescence) or 590 µm (for red fluorescence) emission filter.
source_data.body: Plates may be read in 1-2 weeks, however, it might be preferable to get an initial reading on the plates and monitor progress every 2-3 days. We use the Appliskan plate reader, set to read fluorescent emission using a 485 µm excitation filter and a 675 µm (for green fluorescence) or 590 µm (for red fluorescence) emission filter.
